events.description: Oil prices increased due to fears of supply disruption in the Middle East after Iraq invaded Kuwait.
source: EIA analysis on Gulf War impact (1991)
News archives from The New York Times (August 1990) and CNN (January 1991)

events.description: Economic downturn in Asia led to reduced oil demand, decreasing prices.
source: World Bank and IMF reports on the crisis (1998)
News archives from Reuters (November 1997) and Bloomberg (January 1998)

events.description: OPEC increased production as demand weakened, resulting in oversupply and lower prices.
source: OPEC historical reports (December 1998)
EIA data (November 1998)
Articles from BBC (October 1998) and The Economist (September 1998)

events.description: The 9/11 attacks and ensuing economic downturn decreased oil demand, causing prices to fall.
source: EIA and IEA analyses on economic impacts (September 2001)
News coverage from The New York Times (September 12, 2001) and CNN (September 11, 2001)

events.description: Oil prices increased due to concerns of supply disruptions caused by the U.S. invasion of Iraq.
source: EIA historical price data (April 2003)
IEA reports (March 2003)
News articles from BBC (March 20, 2003) and Reuters (April 2003)

events.event: Global Demand Surge and Financial Speculation
events.description: Rapid economic growth in emerging markets and financial speculation led to oil prices reaching over $140 per barrel.
source: EIA and IEA reports on demand trends (July 2008)
IMF and World Bank economic growth analyses (June 2008)
News from The Wall Street Journal (July 2008) and Financial Times (August 2008)

events.description: Recession reduced demand, leading oil prices to drop from over $140 to around $40 per barrel.
source: EIA and IEA reports on the financial crisis (October 2008)
IMF analysis (November 2008)
News from The Wall Street Journal (December 2008) and Financial Times (January 2009)

events.event: Arab Spring and Libyan Civil War
events.description: Political instability and conflicts in oil-producing countries led to fears of supply disruptions, raising prices.
source: IEA reports on oil supply disruptions (February 2011)
News from Bloomberg (March 2011) and Reuters (April 2011)

events.event: U.S. Shale Boom and OPEC Price War
events.description: Surging U.S. shale oil production and OPEC's decision to maintain production led to oversupply and sharp price drops.
source: EIA reports on shale production (December 2014)
OPEC statements (November 2014)
News articles from Bloomberg (January 2015) and CNBC (February 2015)

events.description: Production cuts by OPEC and allies helped stabilize and raise oil prices by addressing oversupply.
source: OPEC and IEA reports on production agreements (December 2016)
EIA data on production levels (November 2016)
News from Financial Times (January 2017) and CNBC (February 2017)

events.description: Global lockdowns drastically reduced travel and economic activity, causing a historic drop in oil demand and prices.
source: EIA and IEA special reports on COVID-19 (April 2020)
IMF analysis (May 2020)
News articles from BBC (March 2020) and The Guardian (April 2020)

events.event: Post-Pandemic Demand Recovery and Russia-Ukraine War
events.description: Rapid demand recovery post-COVID and the Russia-Ukraine war contributed to oil price spikes.
source: IEA and EIA reports on post-pandemic recovery and the war’s impact on oil supply (March 2022)
News from Bloomberg (April 2022), Reuters (May 2022), and BBC (June 2022)

events.description: Concerns about a global recession and rising interest rates reduced demand expectations, contributing to price declines.
source: IEA and EIA monthly reports (September 2023)
IMF and World Bank economic outlooks (October 2023)
News articles from Financial Times (November 2023) and Wall Street Journal (December 2023)
